subject: Re: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: ... I think I screwed up :-)  You should have read:  ( :-) ) you have to choose the input of your tests so that your tests go through all conditions.  Which is
messageBody:
>>If no variable is updated and it's only the computation of the return
>>value that is executed, you have to choose the input of your tests so
>>that these return values are different. [1]
>
> Why exactly do the return values need to be different?

I think I screwed up :-) You should have read: ( :-) )

you have to choose the input of your tests so that your tests go through
all conditions. Which is nothing new :-)

I was thinking of a method returning one different flag per path. So
the easiest way to check if you have gone through all paths is to [1].

> However, do you really need to know which path the code took?

you only need to be certain that you tested all paths.

> Isn't it sufficient to test that you get the correct return value for
> whatever combinations of input values you choose to test with?

yes and no. writing tests does not guarantee that you have tested all
paths. And since it's impossible to test every input values, a good
alternative is to choose the input value that give you the most feedback.

-Vladimir
